awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Caution and Reference Effects
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how we make decisions is essential to predict economic outcomes and to design optimal policy. Decades of research documented how people often deviate from rationality and tend to do so following specific behavioral patterns. Three of these patterns have been widely documented and are of particular importance in economics: the endowment effect (where the act of ownership increases the value that people associate to a good), loss aversion (the tendency to avoid losses over achieving equivalent gains), and the certainty effect (a bias towards risk-free options, in violation of Expected Utility theory). All three phenomena have been shown to play prominent roles in many contexts, including investment, medical, and educational decisions. In this project, the research teams introduce a new approach to study all three phenomena jointly as stemming from one single intuition: it suggests that all three can originate from the fact that individuals are sometimes unsure of what they prefer and act with caution. This approach makes novel predictions about the relationship of these phenomena and offers a novel tool to organize existing empirical evidence. The team will also conduct also conduct an experiment to test the new predictions of this theory. The results of this project may give us new insights into how to encourage people to save for retirement and protect their health.


The research team wants to demonstrate that all three phenomena above (the endowment effect, loss aversion, and the certainty effect) are captured jointly by the Cautious Utility model. In this model, the individual has a set of utility functions—as if unsure of which one to use—and adopts the most pessimistic one to evaluate each option. The project shows that the Cautious Utility model is characterized axiomatically from imposing a (known) weakening of the independence axiom of Expected Utility that rules out the opposite of the certainty effect. It then shows that this model implies loss aversion and the endowment effect—ruling out the opposite. This establishes a strong theoretical link between these phenomena. They will also show how this model can be used to organize existing empirical evidence, including observations at odds with leading alternative models. Finally, they plan an experiment that tests the critical novel predictions of the Cautious Utility model on the empirical relationship between these phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
An important regularity in how people make decisions and assign values to objects is the “Endowment Effect:” people consistently demand more money to sell an object they own than they would be willing to pay to acquire the same object. In other words, the act of ownership appears to influence the value assigned to the object. This phenomenon plays a central role in behavioral economics both for its conceptual significance—it contradicts the standard assumption of economic theory that a single, well-defined value guides trade and purchasing decisions—and for its practical implications, as it can lead to “no-trade” regions and reduce market efficiency. A large literature has been devoted to studying its implications in various domains, including trade, finance, and public economics. Understanding its origin and modeling it appropriately is essential for predicting its prevalence, analyzing its consequences, and designing policies to mitigate it.

 

This project proposes a novel explanation of the origin of the Endowment Effect, as well as its relationship to other well-known behavioral regularities. We propose that the Endowment Effect emerges from individuals’ uncertainty about the exact value of a given object together with caution. For instance, a person might be unsure whether a given object—say, a mug—is worth $3 or $5. Confronted with this uncertainty, people adopt a criterion of caution. When buying the mug, they err on the side of caution by not paying more than their lower-end estimate, that is, $3; when selling, they remain cautious by not accepting less than their higher-end estimate, $5. We call this model “Cautious Utility.”

 

We show that this model can help us understand and explain existing evidence, including findings that challenge prominent alternative models. In particular, our model predicts more substantial endowment effects for unusual goods and in situations of higher uncertainty or low information—consistent with empirical findings. Furthermore, our model can generate the Endowment Effect without relying on Loss Aversion (the idea that individuals overweight losses), which aligns with recent evidence showing that the Endowment Effect and Loss Aversion are not correlated.

 

Our research makes an additional theoretical contribution by establishing an axiomatic foundation for Cautious Utility. We demonstrate that this model can be obtained by imposing, together with standard axioms, a generalization of a behavioral property that captures the Certainty Effect—another well-documented departure from standard economic theory. This derivation formally connects the Endowment Effect with violations of Expected Utility—an approach that, to our knowledge, is new. This connection between seemingly distinct behavioral phenomena suggests the potential for a unified theoretical framework.

 

Our findings have important implications for both theory and policy. First, they provide a new perspective on the psychological foundations of the Endowment Effect. Second, they suggest specific policy interventions: for example, measures aimed at reducing value uncertainty, such as

enhanced information provision, may help mitigate the Endowment Effect and improve market efficiency.
